remarks: Statement 10 in [Huneke] p. 2:  "If n > 1, then the number of closed n-walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) from v = v(0) = v(n) ... with v(n-2) =/= v is k^(n-2) - f(n-2)."  According to ~ rusgranumwlkg , we have k^(n-2) different walks of length (n-2): v(0) ... v(n-2).  From this number, the number of closed walks of length (n-2), which is f(n-2) per definition, must be subtracted, because for these walks v(n-2) =/= v(0) = v would hold.  Because of the friendship condition, there is exactly one vertex v(n-1) which is a neighbor of v(n-2) as well as of v(n)=v=v(0), because v(n-2) and v(n)=v are different, so the number of walks v(0) ... v(n-2) is identical with the number of walks v(0) ... v(n), that means each (not closed) walk v(0) ... v(n-2) can be extended by two edges to a closed walk v(0) ... v(n)=v=v(0) in exactly one way.  (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 6-Oct-2018.)
statement:

numclwwlk.q $e |- Q = ( v e. V , n e. NN0 |-> { w e. ( ( V WWalksN E ) ` n ) | ( ( w ` 0 ) = v /\ ( lastS ` w ) =/= v ) } ) $.
numclwwlk.h $e |- H = ( v e. V , n e. NN0 |-> { w e. ( C ` n ) | ( ( w ` 0 ) = v /\ ( w ` ( n - 2 ) ) =/= ( w ` 0 ) ) } ) $.
numclwwlk2 $p |- ( ( ( <. V , E >. RegUSGrph K /\ V FriendGrph E ) /\ ( V e. Fin /\ X e. V /\ N e. ( ZZ>= ` 3 ) ) ) -> ( # ` ( X H N ) ) = ( ( K ^ ( N - 2 ) ) - ( # ` ( X F ( N - 2 ) ) ) ) ) $.
